decisions.reason: The hero section uses a split-layout with model image + GSAP clip-path reveal and breathing loop. These 2D CSS/GSAP animations achieve premium visual impact without adding ~150KB+ R3F/Three.js bundle overhead. The clip-path reveal is GPU-accelerated and lighter than canvas-based 3D rendering.
decisions.alternative: GSAP clip-path inset animation + breathing translateY loop

decisions.reason: Standard product views (t-shirts, pants) don't benefit from 3D rotation — flat photography with hover image-swap provides equivalent product understanding at zero GPU cost. 3D would only be justified for complex products (shoes, accessories) requiring true 360° inspection.
decisions.alternative: GSAP crossfade gallery with thumbnail navigation + micro-parallax hover
decisions.condition_to_reconsider: If product line expands to shoes/accessories where interactive 360° viewing demonstrably increases conversion rate (A/B test required)

decisions.reason: 3D adds visual appeal but will increase bundle size (~150KB Three.js + model assets) and GPU usage on mobile devices; recommended to use animated 2D sprite/sequence unless interactive 360° view is explicitly required by product type.

global_policy.justification: Cara is a fashion/lifestyle store selling primarily apparel. 2D photography with GSAP micro-interactions (parallax, crossfade, breathing loops) provides equivalent or better visual engagement than 3D at a fraction of the bundle cost and complexity. R3F adds ~150KB+ gzipped to the JS bundle and requires WebGL support.
global_policy.lazy_load_plan: If R3F is ever added: dynamic(() => import('./R3FViewer'), { ssr: false }) with IntersectionObserver trigger
global_policy.fallback_requirement: All R3F components MUST include a static fallback for non-WebGL devices and prefers-reduced-motion users
